11.25.text:
2014 GSA Design Award Winners
U.S. Land Port of Entry Van Buren,

15.87.text:
Maine The jury found several things
distinctive and award worthy.

20.96.text:
Perhaps the most significant one was the
integration design disciplines in the project

26.97.text:
in a cohesive way, creating a true gateway, one
that projects a welcoming, serene atmosphere.

34.54.text:
Something that we think sets the appropriate
tone for a building that happens to be the Port

39.42.text:
of Entry, the beginning of a visitor
experience to the U.S. One of the things

44.23.text:
that we appreciated quite a lot is
the very simple siting strategy,

48.57.text:
organizing building volumes
in a very compelling way.

53.79.text:
there is a complete sequence of public spaces
that are approachable, accessible to the public

58.84.text:
in the town while there is this
secure operation that takes place

62.14.text: within the boundaries of the project.

67.07.text: Another thing that the jury found interesting

70.15.text:
and extremely well executed
is the material treatment.

73.01.text:
It begins with the building façade There is a
nice gesture to the surrounding forest of Maine

80.71.text:
by having this variegated
texture on the exterior.

84.64.text:
When it comes to the interior of the building,
it's transformed into an expression of vibrancy.

90.75.text: I think the project is quite remarkable.

101.96.text:
Peace Arch, U.S. Land Port of Entry,
Blaine, Washington The jury felt

109.01.text:
that this project really rose
to the level of an honor award

113.77.text: because it succeeded across the board.

118.73.text:
The project achieved a LEED Gold Rating
by lowering its energy consumption,

124.36.text:
reducing light pollution, and doing a
lot of recycling during construction.

129.06.text:
Travelers come up to the building and they
can drive right -- up and over the building.

134.09.text:
The project team put a highway
overpass in the middle of the building,

137.72.text:
and so instead of just having to stop at it
even when you're going out of the country,

142.27.text:
you go up and over, and you get a
delightful view of the tidal bay on one side

148.80.text:
and that connects to the Peace
Arch State Park on the other side.

153.97.text:
The other terrific feature of
the project that really resonated

159.83.text: with the judges was the sculpture Non-Sign.

164.49.text: It's basically the absence of a highway sign.

168.38.text:
The Peace Arch and the Non-Sign picked up
on the same feeling of traveling through

174.41.text:
and the connectivity between the two
countries, between Canada and the United States.

187.66.text:
Edith Green - Wendell Wyatt Federal Building
Portland, Oregon On the most general level,

193.90.text:
I think the jury was very much impressed by the
quality and the extent of the transformation

201.57.text: that took place in that building.

204.65.text:
The building was essentially
remade inside and out.

209.58.text:
And not just in terms of architecture, but
also in terms of its equipment, its heating,

217.52.text:
its cooling, all the aspects of the
building were rethought and remade.

223.79.text:
The transformation that was achieved was one
that made the building into a much more relaxed,

230.26.text: much more animated presence in the city.

232.64.text: And that seemed to us especially commendable.

237.02.text:
So, all of this speaks to a question of
how important it is to think carefully

245.78.text:
about the resources that we have,
whatever their faults may be,

250.57.text:
and about how they can be
transformed to make them more useful,

258.57.text:
And that's what seems to have
been accomplished in this case.

271.82.text: Jacob K. Javits Federal Plaza New York,

274.77.text:
New York The Jacob Javits Plaza is
a space that I've known for years.

281.58.text:
It's a controversial space because
there was a very important piece

284.97.text: of public art there that was removed.

287.79.text:
A landscape by another important
landscape architect, was put in its place.

292.22.text: And then this third iteration was constructed.

295.54.text:
It's interesting to see how an urban
landscape has evolved over time.

301.36.text:
I appreciated the fact that you can relate
to it on a personal scale when you're in it.

307.10.text:
The materials work at a very
refined and detailed level.

310.80.text:
But also when you're looking down at
the space from some of the higher towers

315.91.text:
that surround the area, you get this recognition
of the façade of the Federal Building as sort

321.09.text: of a direct imprint in the paving.

323.10.text: I think this project is a really good example

326.17.text:
of how landscape architecture
can improve the public realm

330.27.text: and how important it is to civic architecture.

345.19.text:
D.C. The Eisenhower Executive
Office Building is truly iconic.

351.05.text:
It stands out because of where it's
placed in relation to the White House,

355.27.text:
but I think it stands out as well because
of its architecture and the intricacies

360.39.text: on the inside and the outside of the building.

363.35.text:
In this particular case we have a building
that was designed over 125 years ago.

369.19.text:
I think the challenge was taking a building
that was built in a very different era

374.12.text:
and modernizing it to bring it into a
different century while still balancing

379.69.text:
and respecting the integrity of the
original design and the historic fabric.

385.04.text:
The construction creatively and
artistically found a way to make all

390.96.text: of the new modern needs invisible.

393.51.text:
Whether it was handrails or whether it was
hiding electrical wiring, it was seamless,

399.63.text: and I think that really stood out for the jury.

409.85.text:
U.S. Courthouse Austin, Texas The
U.S. Courthouse, Austin, Texas,

415.00.text:
is an extraordinary project In plan it looks
very simple; it's a box, but As you move in,

420.87.text:
you realize that they go to great lengths to
make an extraordinary diagonal relationship

426.29.text:
of court and support facilities, They
spent quite a bit of time making sure

431.11.text:
that there's a kind of procession
to these spaces.

433.65.text: And that's really a very difficult thing to do.

436.78.text:
The landscape strategy is more an urbanism
strategy the courthouse comes up to the edge

441.77.text:
of the site and really integrates itself
into the urban planning of Austin.

446.28.text: There's a clever use of storm water management.

448.48.text:
It's not a badge that's trying to
say look at how sustainable we are.

453.94.text:
It's absolutely integrated in the water
collection of the building and the way in which

457.63.text:
that water is then used and
that's very powerful.

466.64.text: Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse New York,

469.25.text:
New York The Thurgood Marshall U.S.
Courthouse, New York, New York.

471.88.text:
Working in any confined environment
is difficult.

474.70.text:
Working in a major city amplifies
that by an order of magnitude.

478.03.text:
I believe what the jury really appreciated
about this renovation of a historic landmark was

483.85.text:
that the final product kept
the soul of the building.

488.32.text:
They did a truly phenomenal job of
moving it into the 21st century.

493.14.text:
The one item that surprised me as an engineer
was their innovative use of abandoned

499.22.text:
or excess elevator shafts to run
some of the mechanical systems.

503.75.text:
Typically you never have enough
space to run the utilities.

507.10.text:
Using those elevator shafts was truly a stroke
of genius Mechanical electrical upgrades,

513.07.text:
energy saving requirements, fire protection,
modern telecommunications standards, --

519.21.text:
are the parts and pieces you need to have
an effective building for the next 50 years.

535.41.text:
Washington Building 1202 is
the new regional headquarters

540.42.text:
of the U.S. Army Corps of
Engineers Northwest District.

544.15.text:
Located within Seattle's
Federal Center South campus,

547.43.text:
it redevelops a brownfield site
previously occupied by a warehouse.

552.30.text:
Jurors praised Building 1202's interior, which
minimizes private offices among 700 employees.

559.66.text:
The open workplace enhances
equity in the organization.

563.75.text:
In addition, juror Susannah Drake pointed
out, "The common spaces encourage collisions

568.86.text:
between colleagues, which make
for a more productive workplace."

572.79.text:
The interactive interior also embodies
an overall focus on sustainability.

577.40.text:
For example, 50-inch-high cubicles
maximize employees' access to light

582.89.text: and views in the narrow building.

585.13.text:
The building's most dramatic common
space, meanwhile, is the atrium,

589.15.text:
which also exhausts indoor air and features
timber salvaged from the previous warehouse.

601.94.text:
Federal Office Building Miramar, Florida This
office nearing completion in Miramar, Florida,

608.24.text:
will become the new South Florida
headquarters of a major government agency.

613.05.text:
The building comprises a linked pair
of 60-foot-wide glass structures;

617.90.text:
the configuration embodies
passive sustainability principles.

622.14.text: Located on 20 acres near the Florida Everglades,

625.54.text:
the project also exemplifies a sustainable
approach to landscape, which jurors lauded.

631.14.text:
Site work is being done to regenerate
wetlands and reintroduce native vegetation.

637.53.text:
The building itself is elevated on
18 inches of repositioned gravel

641.87.text:
to support wetland restoration, and it
incorporates cisterns to manage stormwater.

648.16.text:
The reclaimed landscape will serve the building,
in turn-providing natural site security

653.18.text:
to the federal government and presenting
a welcoming face to the local community.

664.43.text:
11 West Quincy Court Chicago, Illinois
The Bond Department Store opened

673.78.text:
GSA acquired the structure in 2005, and today
the renovated building contributes to the energy

680.08.text:
of State Street by mixing
retail and office uses.

683.98.text:
Modernization integrated the building into the
adjacent Chicago Federal Center campus, as well.

689.40.text:
Turning a former loading dock on
Quincy Court into the new entrance

693.02.text:
for federal employees has
created direct dialogue

696.17.text: between the federal campus and State Street.

699.43.text:
The project also achieved a more
unified appearance for the building.

703.38.text:
One way it did so is by incorporating patterns
from Sol LeWitt's Lines in Four Directions,

708.64.text:
a powder-coated aluminum sculpture mounted
to the former department store's west face.

714.35.text:
Juror Theaster Gates said, "It's one of
the best retrofits I've seen in our city."

726.07.text:
50 United Nations Plaza Federal Building
San Francisco, California Designed

732.11.text: by Arthur Brown Jr. and completed in 1936,

735.76.text:
50 United Nations Plaza Federal
Building is a major component

739.78.text:
of the San Francisco Civic Center,
and a beloved local landmark.

743.96.text:
Commenting on the building's recent
seismic upgrade and overall modernization,

748.39.text:
juror Estevan Rael-Galvez said: "There are very
good reasons for keeping this building adding,

754.40.text:
"This project provided the opportunity
to bring it into the next century.

758.28.text:
It was readily adapted without
compromising its soul."

762.12.text:
The modernization was the first major upgrade
of 50 United Nations Plaza since 1936.

768.53.text:
The work exercised great care
toward the historic fabric,

774.62.text:
It also redesigned office space for
new patterns of open and mobile work.

786.36.text: Dr. A.H. Mccoy Federal Building Jackson,

789.26.text:
Mississippi Updating the Dr. A.H. McCoy Federal
Building in downtown Jackson, Mississippi,

795.54.text:
offered the opportunity to
reinvent its public plaza.

798.89.text:
The original outdoor space was
disconnected from the city grid,

802.21.text:
and the 1979 building's imposing
architecture further discouraged public use.

808.17.text:
Because modernization included
construction of a security pavilion,

812.11.text:
the new structure was designed
to reach into the broad plaza.

815.86.text:
"It's a very organic, cyclical shape, and
very much counter to the Brutalist building,"

820.71.text:
juror Lucille Tenazas said of the entry, which
is clad in more than 1,000 glass shingles.

826.67.text:
Alongside new site landscaping, the
pavilion reestablishes the street edge.

831.92.text:
Inside, its curved geometry directs
visitors intuitively through security

845.99.text:
Federal Office Building Andover, Massachusetts
Modernization of this federal office building

852.11.text:
in Andover, Massachusetts,
corresponds with the IRS's conversion

856.06.text: from paper tax returns to digital files.

859.13.text:
The warehouse-like space has been
transformed into a professional office

863.13.text:
for accounts management,
compliance services, and support.

866.92.text:
The building interior is
organized into six neighborhoods,

870.14.text: which employees reach via diagonal boulevards.

873.19.text:
The facility also includes new glass entry
pavilions, adjoining lobbies, dining areas,

878.74.text: and other interior and outdoor amenities,

881.14.text:
which serve as navigational
landmarks and places for meeting.

885.05.text:
Jurors praised the redesign
for imparting a sense or order

888.52.text:
where there had not been a
hierarchy of spaces previously.

891.79.text:
The scheme improved the character
of the building, moreover,

894.89.text:
and created opportunities
for employee interaction.

907.51.text:
West Virginia The IRS Enterprise Computing
Center in Kearneysville, West Virginia,

913.12.text: "is really a stunning example of contract

915.29.text:
and construction management,"
said juror Peter Marshall.

918.40.text:
As part of the facility's conversion
to static uninterruptible power,

922.19.text:
this project constructed a
replacement utility plant

928.44.text:
A phasing plan accounted for
temporary equipment and connections,

932.39.text: demolition of equipment, and equipment transfer.

935.13.text:
The project also included
civil design of an access road

938.19.text: and relocation site for existing utility mains.

941.77.text:
"IRS computers can't be knocked offline, so this
effort took an immense amount of coordination

946.79.text:
by multiple design and construction
teams," Marshall noted.

950.25.text: "The benefit to the taxpayer is a more thorough,

952.57.text:
reliable system that will
function for the next 50 years."

965.35.text:
Indiana The 40-year-old Minton-Capehart
Federal Building was planned

969.95.text: as a narrow tower in downtown Indianapolis.

972.73.text:
Local architect Evans Woollen instead
shaped the office as a broad mid-rise,

977.04.text:
claiming the design would better relate
to Veterans Memorial Plaza next door.

981.29.text:
The move created both an anchor and a large
canvas for the renowned artist Milton Glaser,

986.01.text:
whose exterior mural Color Fuses was a
commission of GSA's Art in Architecture program.

991.20.text:
The 1975 artwork wrapped the building's
arcade in bands of color-about

998.85.text:
"The mural played a very strong role
in the urbanism of this project.

1002.66.text:
It drew people into the building
with an incredible economy of means."

1007.10.text:
Modernization of the Minton-Capehart Federal
Building included restoration of Color Fuses.

1012.43.text:
With Glaser's participation, the project team
undertook analysis, cleaning, and repainting.

1017.72.text:
Installation of pulsing LEDs allows the artwork
to be seen as Glaser originally intended.

1029.89.text: John M. Roll United States Courthouse Yuma,

1032.76.text:
Arizona The John M. Roll United States
Courthouse is a new courthouse located

1040.35.text:
Jury chair Henry Cobb noted, "The
building makes a civic gesture,"

1044.35.text:
while providing much-needed space
to the United States Courts.

1048.18.text:
One of the building's most notable contributions
to the community is its shaded public plaza.

1053.47.text:
It is formed by a 10,000-square-foot canopy,
which resembles historic local structures known

1058.66.text:
as ramadas: Instead of cactus
and other native plants,

1062.15.text:
the courthouse canopy is
made of weathered steel.

1065.13.text:
The canopy roof is finished
in photovoltaics, as well.

1068.48.text:
These solar panels generate approximately
21 percent of the building's electricity.

1079.56.text:
United States Courthouse Bakersfield,
California Overlooking Mill Creek Park

1084.94.text:
in downtown Bakersfield, California,
the United States Courthouse

1088.44.text:
in Bakersfield continues the tradition
of the courthouse on the village green.

1092.47.text:
The new building also adapts this tradition
to California's modernist architecture:

1097.02.text:
Concrete panels on the west face of
the building are placed diagonally,

1100.78.text:
better displaying courthouse
activity to the park.

1103.54.text:
This indoor-outdoor relationship also benefits
the building interior, filling it with daylight.

1109.21.text:
The south-facing entry reinterprets
the historic courthouse, as well.

1113.13.text:
Here the classic portico is
transformed into a recessed portal.

1117.27.text:
Juror David Adjaye remarked, "The design
is deceptively simple; it understands how

1122.32.text:
to use very little to create
a very civic building.

1132.15.text:
United States Courthouse Annex San Diego,
California The United States Courthouse Annex

1137.84.text: in downtown San Diego expands facilities

1140.43.text:
for the Edward J. Schwartz Federal
Building and U.S. Courthouse.

1144.20.text:
Public users enter the new annex
through a lobby that is set apart

1147.53.text:
from the 16-story building
for optimal visibility.

1150.78.text:
The lobby and adjacent jury assembly
are designed for natural ventilation,

1154.54.text: taking advantage of the temperate climate.

1156.45.text: Thanks to the tower's overall narrowness,

1159.05.text:
the annex enjoys significant
daylighting throughout its interior.

1163.25.text:
This project also developed the
plaza between old and new courthouses

1166.90.text: to serve residents and building users alike.

1169.83.text:
In one example, Hedge Wedge, by Robert Irwin,
ramps upward to the annex's elevated lobby:

1175.60.text:
The public artwork resolves the height
difference between the plaza and building,

1179.16.text: and makes both appear more approachable.

1188.30.text:
Wayne N. Aspinall Federal Building
And U.S. Courthouse Grand Junction,

1192.15.text:
Colorado The Wayne N. Aspinall Federal Building
and U.S. Courthouse in Grand Junction, Colorado,

1198.29.text:
was constructed in 1918 by the Treasury
Department under James A. Wetmore.

1203.13.text:
Today the landmark building is poised to
be GSA's first net-zero-energy building.

1208.38.text:
Modernization of the three-story facility
prioritized environmental performance

1214.98.text:
A rooftop photovoltaic canopy was
set back to minimize intrusion

1218.75.text:
to the building's original
appearance, for example.

1220.92.text:
And efficient new mechanical, electrical,
and life-safety systems were installed

1225.48.text:
without disturbing arched
lobby openings or interfering

1231.15.text:
Juror Susannah Drake commented: "The project
team conserved the parts of the building

1235.42.text:
with the most historic value, and
used less prominent elevations

1238.67.text: and other elements to address new program.

1250.06.text: United States Courthouse Toledo, Ohio Toledo,

1253.88.text:
Ohio established a civic center
mall in its downtown in 1924.

1258.44.text:
This proposed federal courthouse in Toledo
anchors the northern edge of the mall,

1264.95.text: The project's design, on the other hand,

1269.71.text:
A mounded roof and glass atrium
reinvent the classic dome and portico,

1273.75.text:
and the curtain wall's curved
panels suggest fluting on a column.

1277.80.text:
Of the courthouse's planning and
architectural design, juror David Adjaye said,

1282.53.text:
"The plan's relationship with a City
Beautiful-era mall is very convincing.

1286.93.text:
It creates a fantastic belvedere
from which to see the site.

1290.30.text:
The proposal also offers an interesting
new direction for familiar forms.

1294.61.text:
The jury applauds experimenting
with civic topology."
